Raising the parable of the blind men describing an elephant
Clarifying the meaning of buddha-nature not being identical to the six dharmas but not separate from the six dharmas

Clarifying that buddha-nature is the twelve links of dependent arising and faith, etc. Distinguishing the characteristics of a bodhisattva's irreversibility, such as eating one sesame seed and one bean a day, etc. Explaining the matter of a bodhisattva offering his body to sentient beings and making vows. Explaining the matter of a bodhisattva enduring suffering for sentient beings without turning back. The eighth chapter on the lion's roar, the ninth chapter. Good man!
It is like a king who tells a great minister... Therefore, form is said to be buddha-nature.
Commentary:
The phrase each touching it with their hands is a metaphor for hearing and seeing.
They all do not speak of the elephant's body, but only see what is not the elephant.
The phrase it is also not the case that they do not speak of it means that each obtains its part, and it is not the case that it is not spoken of.

The phrase form is buddha-nature means that the nature of the correct cause is different, and the fruition that is produced is also different. Attaching to one-sidedness is a mistake, like the golden color being the same but the coiled snake being different.
Commentary:
The second turn.
It clarifies that the nature spoken of by the TathÄgata is different. Since the nature of ordinary beings is true and without error, it should be cultivated.
The king is a metaphor for the Buddha, the ministers are metaphors for the teachings of the eternal sÅ«tras, and the elephant is a metaphor for the principle below the teachings.
The blind person speaks of the elephant according to what they touch. Sentient beings lack wisdom and thus conceive of the self based on the aggregates.
Those who say the self exists apart from the aggregates have a view that is too extreme. This will be refuted below.
Not being the six dharmas and not apart from the six dharmas means that the five aggregates form a provisional person.
Buddha-nature is in the fruit. How can it be the six dharmas?
Without causes, there is no way to give rise to the fruit. Therefore, it is said that it is not apart from them.
Baoliang says:
If the blind person touches the elephant and looks at each part, they do not get the whole elephant.
However, they also do not get the elephant apart from these parts.

Non-Buddhists and ordinary beings grasp the five aggregates and each part apart from the aggregates, thinking they are not the Buddha-nature. However, they are ultimately not apart from these six dharmas.

There are some non-Buddhists who say there is a self but in reality there is no self. This refutes the sixth view that there is a self outside of the five aggregates. It means the five aggregates are provisionally combined and called sentient beings, and there is no separate self outside of the five aggregates.
Some say that feeling is the Buddha-nature, up to and including not being a self but not apart from a self.
Commentary:
Above it mentioned form, now it mentions mind, referring to the four aggregates of mind.

Great compassion is called the Buddha-nature, up to and including the Buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Commentary:
Explaining the nature of the enabling cause, which all sentient beings will definitely attain, is called existence.
The continuity is no different, which is the TathÄgata.

Fourth, traversing the enabling cause.
The four immeasurable practices are precisely the enabling cause. Good bodhisattvas always practice them, like a shadow following a form.

The name buddha-nature refers to the TathÄgata. Practicing the four immeasurables, one will soon attain the stage of the first abode, and in the distant future, one will fully attain buddhahood, thus called the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the great mind of faith... all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Seng Liang said:

Good sons!
As explained above, various dharmas... all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.

Good sons!

Seng Liang said:
If it is said that form is buddha-nature and the rest are not, then sentient beings with wrong views will certainly give rise to perversions upon hearing this.
Good man!
If sentient beings understand buddha-nature, they will be able to uphold, read, recite, and explain this sutra for others, and will also praise and pay homage to those who uphold it.

The World-Honored One has attained supreme, perfect enlightenment.

World-Honored One!

Previously, because there is a nature, therefore it encourages cultivation.
The practitioner's work becomes increasingly profound, and he no longer regresses;

Such ascetic practices are mostly before abiding.

This clarifies that a wise person practices in accordance with the sutra, obtains the flavor of its principles, and never regresses again.

Commentary:
The seventh is the gate of the characteristic of non-retrogression.

Cultivating the path necessarily involves birth and death, but birth and death have many difficulties, and one cannot know oneself whether one will regress or not regress, so next it distinguishes the characteristics of non-retrogression.
Furthermore, good man!

The ocean has eight virtues, which are used to illustrate the sutra.
First, due to the blessings of sentient beings, the ocean gradually deepens.
Sentient beings have feelings, so the teachings of the sutra gradually progress from shallow to deep.
Second, following the wind, the buddhas and bodhisattvas transform in accordance with conditions.
Third, entering the river water, it clarifies the vessel that receives the myriad lives of nirvana.
